body_text.text: Based on a sample of 1.31 × 10 9 J/ψ events collected with the BESIII detector at the BEPCII collider, Dalitz plot analyses of selected 79,625 η → π + π − π 0 events, 33,908 η → π 0 π 0 π 0 events and 1,888 η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 events are performed.
The measured matrix elements of η → π + π − π 0 are in reasonable agreement with previous measurements.

The Dalitz plot slope parameters of η → π 0 π 0 π 0 and η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 are determined to be −0.055±0.014±0.004 and −0.640±0.046±0.047, respectively, where the first uncertainties are statistical and the second systematic.
Both values are consistent with previous measurements, while the precision of the latter one is improved by a factor of three.
Final state interactions are found to have an important role in those decays.

body_text.text: II.
DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION
BEPCII is a double-ring e + e − collider working at center-of-mass energies from 2.0 to 4.6 GeV.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The BESIII [20] detector at BEPCII collider, with a geometrical acceptance of 93% of 4π stereo angle, operates in a 1.0 T (0.9 T in 2012, when about 83% of the data sample were collected) magnetic field provided by a superconducting solenoid magnet.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The detector is composed of a helium-based drift chamber (MDC), a plastic-scintillator time-of-flight (TOF) system, a CsI(Tl) electromagnetic calorimeter (EMC) and a multi-layer resistive plate counter system (MUC).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The charged-particle momentum resolution at 1.0 GeV/c is 0.5%, and the specific energy loss (dE/dx) resolution is better than 6%.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The spatial resolution of the MDC is better than 130 µm.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The time resolution of the TOF is 80 ps in the barrel and 110 ps in the endcaps.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The energy resolution of the EMC at 1.0 GeV/c is 2.5% (5%) in the barrel (endcaps), and the position resolution is better than 6 mm (9 mm) in the barrel (endcaps).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The position resolution in the MUC is better than 2 cm.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Monte Carlo (MC) simulations are used to estimate backgrounds and determine the detection efficiencies.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The GEANT4-based [21] simulation software BOOST [22] includes the geometric and material description of the BESIII detector, detector response, and digitization models, as well as the tracking of the detector running conditions and performance.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The production of the J/ψ resonance is simulated with KKMC [23,24], while the decays are generated with EVTGEN [25] for known decay modes with branching fractions being set to the world average values [5] and by LUNDCHARM [26] for the remaining unknown decays.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: We use a sample of 1.2 × 10 9 simulated J/ψ events where the J/ψ decays generically ('inclusive MC sample') to identify background contributions.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The analysis is performed in the framework of the BESIII offline software system (BOSS) [27] which takes care of the detector calibration, event reconstruction, and data storage.

body_text.text: SUMMARY Using 1.31 × 10 9 J/ψ events collected with the BESIII detector, the Dalitz plots of η → π + π − π 0 and η/η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 are analyzed and the corresponding matrix elements are extracted.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: In the case of charge conjugation invariance, the Dalitz plot matrix elements for η → π + π − π 0 are determined to be a = −1.128 ± 0.015 ± 0.008, b = 0.153 ± 0.017 ± 0.004, d = 0.085 ± 0.016 ± 0.009, f = 0.173 ± 0.028 ± 0.021, where the first errors are statistical and the second ones systematic, here and in the following.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: In Fig. 6 our measurement is compared to previous measurements and theoretical predictions.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: Our results are in agreement with the two most recent measurements, and consistent with the predictions of the dispersive approach and ChPT at NNLO level.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: To investigate the charge conjugation violation in η → π + π − π 0 , the matrix elements c and e have been determined from a fit to the data.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: The obtained values are consistent with zero, while the other parameters are found to be consistent with those obtained from the fit assuming charge conjugation invariance.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: No significant charge symmetry breaking is observed.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: After taking into account the systematic uncertainties, the slope parameter α for η → π 0 π 0 π 0 is measured to be −0.055 ± 0.014 ± 0.004.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: A comparison to previous works, illustrated in Fig. 7(a), indicates that the BESIII result is compatible with the recent results from other experiments and in agreement with the prediction from ChPT at NNLO within two standard deviations of the theoretical uncertainties.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: The Dalitz plot slope parameter for η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 is measured to be α = −0.640 ± 0.046 ± 0.047, which is consistent with but more precise than previous measurements ( Fig. 7(b)).
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: The value deviates significantly from zero.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: This implies that final state interactions play an important role in the decay.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: Up to now, there are just a few predictions about the slope parameter of η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 .
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: In Ref.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: [29], the slope parameter is predicted to be less than 0.03, which is excluded by our measurement.
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: More recently, using a chiral unitary approach, an expansion of the decay amplitude up to the fifth and sixth order of X and Y has been used to parameterize the Dalitz plot of η ′ → π 0 π 0 π 0 [30].
body_text.section: Source

body_text.text: The coefficient, which corresponds to α in this paper, is found to be in the range between −2.7 and 0.1, consistent with our measurement.
